results.title: Victoria
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Holiday”.
Rich in history and culture, Victoria also boasts a fine selection of food and spectacular natural landscapes. Melbourne’s main attractions open the program including trams, tree-lined boulevards, splendid buildings and magnificent gardens. Its country and coastal regions offer visitors a diverse range of activities from horse riding in the Great Dividing Ranges, experiencing the gold rush at Sovereign Hill, ‘cruising’ Lake Eildon, visiting Flagstaff Hill Maritime Museum, relaxing at Daylesford and Hepburn Springs, rock-climbing at Mount Arapiles and for the gourmet traveller a residential cooking school at Howqua Dale.

results.title: Tax is not a four letter word
results.creator_credit: Michael Mills, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A musical cartoon produced for the Department of National Revenue, Canada. It is about the most misunderstood servant of us all, the income tax collector. But in this film he no longer remains unloved, unsung, once people understand that the money he collects is really for everyone’s benefit. A bright, amusing film for any time of year, tax time or not.

results.title: Tati shorts
results.brief_description: The characters in these three short films will be familiar territory to fans of actor/director Jacques Tati. “Soigne ton Gauche=Watch your Left” (12 mins. 1936) directed by Rene Clement, focuses on a boxer whose training suffers considerable upheaval when he is joined in the ring by Tati bearing many traits of what would later become the Hulot character. This film has some French dialogue but the soundtrack is ambient rather than specific. “L’Ecole des Facteurs=School for Postmen” (15 mins. 1947) sees Tati approach his studies in a confused and enthusiastic manner. This character would go on to reap global fame as Francois the Postman in ‘Jour de Fete’. In “Cours du Soir=Evening Classes” (28 mins. 1967) Tati’s portrayal of a teacher presents an amalgam of Hulot and Francois allowing both characters full comic reign in the classroom.

results.title: Techniques
results.creator_credit: Eve Cotton and Center for Humanities
results.brief_description: By analysing and comparing great paintings from different periods, this series provides a unique introduction to art. This program examines the techniques used to produce different styles of painting. The techniques examined are: fresco, tempera and oil, water colour, pastel and prints.

results.title: Teamwork in farm research
results.creator_credit: George Bloomfield, Barrie Angus McLean and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An example of the modern approach of agricultural scientists to problems that affect the farming industry, the film gives an account of how a coumarin-free variety of sweet clover, under certain silage conditions, developed a poisonous mould. From a few test seedlings, through a whole program of cross-breeding, the film shows how the nutritionally safe “Cumino” variety of sweet clover was finally produced in commercial quantities.

results.title: Teaching sport skills to young athletes (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Barton Cox and Barton Cox, Jr Films
results.brief_description: Gives coaches some guide lines for planning and conducting efficient practices and how to effectively teach specific sport skills. Stresses the importance of planning activities for the whole season ahead.

results.title: Teach me to dance
results.creator_credit: Anne Wheeler, Vladimir Valenta and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Lesia convinces her English-Canadian friend Sarah to perform a Ukrainian dance with her as part of their school’s Christmas pageant. However, Sarah’s father objects. Angry at the growing number of Ukrainian settlers, he will not allow his daughter to do the Ukrainian dance with Lesia. But in spite of the prejudices of their parents, the girls’ friendship remains strong, and they meet in Sarah’s barn to celebrate Christmas Day together. Award: Milan. Story and screenplay by Myrna Kostash. Suitable for upper primary and middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Tchou-tchou
results.creator_credit: Co Hoedeman, Pierre Moretti and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A children’s fantasy where building blocks and musical effects do everything. Blocks represent the make-believe city and the two children who play in it. Blocks act out the story when an angry dragon appears on the scene and the music underscores the action. The puppet theatre is so colourfully presented that everyone is absorbed and entertained. A film without words. (Awards: five including London; Annecy)
